thread.title: Sanders laughs off Clinton's subtle accusation of sexism
thread.title_full: Sanders laughs off Clinton's subtle accusation of sexism | Washington Examiner

author: Gabby Morrongiello
title: Sanders laughs off Clinton's subtle accusation of sexism
text:
Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders' recent accusation that Hillary Clinton "shouts" when she discusses guns was entirely unrelated to her gender, Sanders told CNN on Sunday.
During a campaign speech Friday in Alexandria, Va., the former secretary of state told supporters she'd "been told to stop shouting about guns," in a clear reference to Sanders.
"Actually, I haven't been shouting, but sometimes when a woman talks, some people think it's shouting," Clinton said.
"She's basically calling you a sexist," CNN's Jake Tapper told Sanders on Sunday. "She is suggesting, in public, that you have a problem with women speaking out."
  Poll: 85 percent of voters think the U.S. is on wrong track Additionally,     fragile."
By Gabby Morrongiello • 10/25/15 5:46 PM Sanders, a socialist who is in second place in the Democratic field behind Clinton, briefly chuckled before responding to Tapper.
"Well, uh, all I can say is I am very proud of my record on women's issues," he said.
Adding, " I certainly do not have a problem with women speaking out, and I think what the secretary is doing there is taking words and misapplying them."
Sanders then tried to clarify that his remark about Clinton's raised tone of voice was meant to be taken more broadly.
"What I was saying is that if we are going to make some progress in dealing with these horrific massacres that we're seeing, is that people have got to start all over this country talking to each other," he said.
Also from the Washington Examiner Press takes Planned Parenthood's word that videos were 'edited' Many reporters claim that the tapes have been deceptively edited, but few have admitted to watching them.
By Becket Adams • 10/25/15 12:01 AM "It's not Hillary Clinton. You have some people who are shouting at other people all across this country. You know that. This nation is divided on this issue."
Sanders and Clinton held dueling campaign rallies in Iowa on Saturday, hours before the two candidates appeared at the annual Jefferson-Jackson fundraising dinner hosted by Democrats in the earliest voting state.

By Curt Mills • 10/25/15 10:23 AM
